text: [MUSIC] My name is Zach Scheel.
I'm the co-founder and CEO of Rhumbix,
and I participated in the entrepreneurship and
civil environmental engineering program in spring of 2014.
My co-founder and I, ah,
had been working on it, ah,
on Rhumbix for a couple months, but, ah,
the program really provided a structured course that got us all
the way to where we needed to be to go out and begin fundraising,
ah, as soon as we graduated and finish the course.
The biggest success as an entrepreneur is,
is us being here today at the Rhumbix office.
Ah, we're in the middle of ramping from 35 to 50 employees.
Ah, we've raised 30 million in,
in capital over the course of the last five years.
And, um, yeah the fact that I'm sitting here today I give you this interview is,
is the biggest success,
ah, as an entrepreneur today.
Really one of the things that brought me to the program,
ah, with the professors that teach it , um,
they've got an unbelievable wealth of experience from
venture capital to be an entrepreneurs themselves.
Um, really having gone through,ah,
every stage of early-stage startup life.
So the program curriculum is basically
a crash course for everything and I need to know to start a company.
Ah, it covers, ah, initial team makeup, ah, to,
um, settling on a minimum viable product to how do you bring that product to market?
How do you finance it?
How do you, ah, continue to scale it?
So it really is an A to Z program covering,
um, all stages of early stage startups live.
The program was invaluable in teaching
us everything that we needed to know to start a company.
Ah, we graduated in June 2014, ah,
and closer for seed financing round in,
ah, August of that year.
Ah, really took what we learned in the program, ah,
and we are able to, um, ah,
generate a convertible note to begin fund raising
almost immediately from graduate from the class.
Biggest challenge, ah, for my co-founder and myself as
non technical co-founders was building the software [LAUGHTER] ah, company.
We'd never, ah, recruited, um,
screen hired, ah, or managed,
ah, software developers and engineers before.
So, ah, that was a real, ah,
learning curve that we had to go up and, um,
the course provided us with a network of people that we were able to lean on, ah,
throughout that process, ah,
to provide a support and mentorship and advice.
The program instructors' expertise was invaluable, ah,
really leveraged Ray Levitt to think about, um,
our go to market and our minimum viable product within the construction industry,
ah, talk to folks like Pedram and Mike about,
ah, raising initial venture capital, ah,
who are the folks that we need to be talking to, ah,
and how should we think about, ah,
initial finances for the round in the early stages.
It's not a stretch of the imagination to say that we
would not be anywhere near as successful as we are today,
ah, without what we learned in entrepreneurship and civil and environmental engineering.
Um, my co-founder and I like to require,
like to refer to it as having grown up supervision,
ah, at the very early stages of the company.
And, um, professors really help put us on a path for success from the onset.
My advice for potential students in the program is, is dream big.
Um, don't, don't go into the program,
um, you know with, with small aspirations.
Um, really the program sets you up,ah,
to be a venture-backed company,
um, and, and to be a venture-backed company and attract capital,
ah, you need a large addressable market.
That's one of the things you'll learn in the class,
and, um, and so dream big,
um, and, um, you know the sky's the limit don't let anything hold you back.
